etymologies: Middle English. From bere + bind, perhaps reflecting an unattested Old English *berebinde; with the second element compare also bind. So called on account of its habit of winding round and binding together stalks of barley

definitions: Any of various European bindweeds or similar twining plants; especially field bindweed, Convolvulus arvensis, and black bindweed, Fallopia convolvulus.

notes.text: Now chiefly in lists of alternative names for these plants.
